result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt: Hearing on November 14, 2022 at 08:30 am.

8:48 AM Defendant Brandon W. Anderson in court.  Attorney Basil Martin Loeb in court for Brandon W. Anderson. District Attorney's Office Law Intern appeared for the State of Wisconsin by Jack Rieder. 

Defense requests to conduct preliminary hearing waiver waiver.  

Defendant waives his/her right to a Preliminary Hearing. Court conducts colloquy with the Defendant re: waiver of preliminary hearing. Court binds Defendant over for trial as it relates to count #1. Information filed. Defense acknowledges receipt. Reading is waived.   NOT GUILTY PLEA ENTERED. 

Defense is requesting a further proceeding date the 2nd week of November. Defense is awaiting discovery from the State on 22CF540.
Hearing scheduled for November 14, 2022 at 08:30 am.
Hearing on October 24, 2022 at 08:30 am.

9:11 AM Defendant Brandon W. Anderson in court.  Attorney Basil Martin Loeb in court for Brandon W. Anderson.  Prosecuting attorney Randy P. Sitzberger in court for the State of Wisconsin. Victim rights have been complied with by the Waukesha County District Attorneys Office. 

Defense sent a proposal to the state to resolve cases globally, and requests a status. 
State will make note of proposal for responsible DA to review.
Hearing scheduled for October 24, 2022 at 08:30 am.
Atty Loeb appears on behalf of the Defendant

dates not changed on bond - per WSD money was posted on 9/13/22

10:17 AM Defendant Brandon W. Anderson in court, in custody. District Attorney's Office Law Intern appeared for the State of Wisconsin by Abigail Kincheloe.  Victim rights have been complied with by the Waukesha County District Attorneys Office. 

Court advises of right to an attorney. Defendant states he wishes to be represented by an Attorney "in the future". 

Defendant states that he has not received the most recent reports. 

Defendant believes he is competent to proceed in these proceedings.
State does not dispute the findings made in the last report. 

For reasons stated on the record, the Court will find that the Defendant is declaring that he is competent, and finds that the Defendant is competent to proceed. 

Defendant states he would like to re-retain Atty Basil Loeb. Court will set over for hearing on status of counsel.
Hearing scheduled for September 20, 2022 at 09:00 am.

records.descr: DE not competent to stand trial, case suspended

records.addlTxt:
Order of Commitment for Treatment (incompetency).
Signed by Judge Brad D. Schimel on 06/17/22.
Review hearing on September 12, 2022 at 10:00 am.

Patrick Ryan Campbell appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Defendant Brandon W. Anderson in court, in custody.  
Dr. Deborah Collins appeared by zoom.
Court to Address:  Competency Hearing.

Dr. Collins did file a competency evaluation on 05/10/22 - Finding the defendant is not competent but likely to regain within the statutory time frame.
Defendant is contesting the findings - Believes he is competent to proceed.

Witness Called:  Dr. Deborah Collins (Board Certified - Forensic Psychologist).
Witness Sworn and Testified.

State presented arguments to the court.
Defendant presented arguments to the court.

Court finds the defendant is currently not competent to proceed, but likely to regain within the statutory time frame.
Therefore, the Court will commit the defendant to the Department of Health Services on an in-custody/in-patient basis for purposes of treatment.
Court will order the defendant be transferred to a mental health facility as soon as bed space is available for purposes of treatment.
Court will also order involuntary administration of medications, not competent to refuse treatment or medications.
Court will grant 82 days of sentence credit as of today's date.

  Review hearing scheduled for September 12, 2022 at 10:00 am.
Competency hearing on June 17, 2022 at 01:30 pm.
Competency hearing on June 17, 2022 at 11:00 am.

Susan L. Opper appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Defendant Brandon W. Anderson in court, in custody.  
Court to Address:  Competency Evaluation Prepared by Dr. Collins - Findings are the Defendant is Not Competent But Likely to regain within the Statutory Time Frame - Recommending in-patient treatment.

State has received a copy of the evaluation and is not contesting the findings or requesting a second evaluation.
Defendant is contesting the findings - defendant states he is competent.
Clerk contacted the Public Defender's Office and they will add the defendant to the list for purposes of evaluation.
Court advises of right to an attorney.
Dr. Collins to appear in person.  Competency hearing scheduled for June 17, 2022 at 11:00 am.
filed by Dr. Deborah L. Collins.
Letter from defendant's family member regarding defendant's ability to represent himself.
Review hearing on May 16, 2022 at 08:30 am.
Signed by Commissioner Costello on April 11, 2022.

08:39 AM Defendant Brandon W. Anderson in court, in custody.  Patrick Ryan Campbell appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  The defendant states he does not wish to be represented by counsel.  THE COURT SUA SPONTE ORDERS FOR COMPETENCY PURSUANT TO SEC.. 971.14(2).  Court orders the defendant be examined by the Wisconsin Forensic Unit.  To be done as an outpatient basis within 30 days.  Court tolled time limits for preliminary hearing.  The Court will set this matter before the Trial Court for review on competency.  Bail remains as fixed.  Review hearing scheduled for May 16, 2022 at 08:30 am.
Multiple letters from defendant's family members regarding defendant's ability to represent himself.
